College of Chemistry and Material Science Langfang Normal University Langfang 065000 China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, College of Chemistry, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering College of Chemistry Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China Photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2PR) into hydrocarbons is one of the most promising technologies to address global energy demand and environmental issues, and vacancy engineering can significantly enhance the activity of photocatalysts in CO2PR. Herein, the structure, charge properties of vacant ZnAl-LDHs (hydrogen vacancy: VH, hydroxyl vacancy: VOH, zinc vacancy: VZn) and the thermodynamic mechanism of CO2PR over these LDHs are investigated by using density functional theory. The calculation results indicate that the introduction of vacancies can promote the adsorption and activation of reactant CO2. Compared to perfect ZnAl-LDH, introducing vacancies can reduce the Gibbs free energy barriers for CO2PR to CO and CH4. The analysis of the Gibbs free energy barriers of potential-determining step (ΔG PDS) and HER suggests that VOH-ZnAl-LDH is the best CO2PR catalyst. By comparing the adsorption of reactants and intermediate species at different positions on the catalyst, it is found that species adsorption at vacancies is more conducive to the occurrence of catalytic reactions. Regulating the OH concentrations on the surface of LDHs also affects the catalytic activity of the catalyst, and when the concentration is 2/9, it has the lowest Gibbs free energy (0.258 eV) barrier for CO2PR to CH4. This work provides theoretical guidance for understanding the photocatalytic performance of LDHs materials containing vacancies for CO2PR, and provides useful directions for designing and preparing efficient CO2PR catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Vacant layered double hydroxides Density functional theory CO2PR Vacancy concentration Mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the main greenhouse gas that causes global warming [1]. Excessive emissions of CO2 can cause sustained global temperature rise, seriously disrupting the carbon balance of nature, and posing a great threat to the stability of ecosystems and human survival [1,2]. Therefore, exploring a method that can reduce the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere while converting it into valuable fuels and chemicals is of great practical significance [3]. Utilizing renewable solar energy to drive CO2 reduction can simultaneously solve global energy and environmental problems, which is a promising technology [4,5]. However, due to the high bond energy of C=O (805 kJ·mol−1) in CO2 structure, limited surface active sites of the catalyst, or poor adsorption of CO2, the photoreduction efficiency and product selectivity are not satisfactory [6,7]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a widely used two-dimensional layered anionic clay material composed of positively charged hydroxide layers and negatively charged interlayer guests [8]. In recent years, due to the adjustable nature of the host layers and interlayer guest anions, it has been possible to regulate their surface charge distribution and other electronic properties, which is of great significance for achieving selective regulation of photocatalytic CO2 reduction products [9,10]. At present, various LDHs materials such as NiAl-, CoAl-, ZnAl- have been applied in photocatalytic reduction of CO2, and C1 compounds such as CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, CH4 have been obtained [10–12]. However, the limited exposed surface, competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and high electron-hole recombination rate greatly reduce the efficiency of converting solar energy into chemical energy [13]. In order to overcome these problems and achieve the application requirements of large-scale photocatalytic reduction of CO2, many novel strategies such as element doping, crystal engineering, and vacancy engineering have been designed to optimize the LDHs catalytic reaction process [14–16]. Among them, vacancy engineering not only can regulate the chemical environment of the reaction active sites and coordination valence state of catalysts. Currently, many studies have shown that introducing vacancy sites on the catalysts surface can promote the formation of unsaturated metal centers and enhance the inherent activity of reaction sites [17–19]. Zhao et al. reported that surface vacancies (such as oxygen vacancies (VO), metal vacancies) in CuCr-LDH not only act as active adsorption sites, but also enhance photocatalytic activity under light irradiation up to 500 nm [20]. Xu et al. reported that ZnAl-LDH containing oxygen vacancies and Zn vacancies can lead the formation of coordinatively unsaturated Zn and Zn+-Vo complexes, which can enhance the adsorption of reactant CO2, promote photoinduced charge separation, and significantly improve the catalytic activity of the reaction [21]. Although many studies have shown that the introduction of metal vacancies (VM) and hydroxyl vacancies(VOH) in LDHs can effectively regulate the catalytic activity of LDHs for photocatalytic CO2 reduction (CO2PR) [22], it is currently unclear how vacancies affect the structure activity connectivity of LDHs materials. The most interesting thing is that the relationship between the coordinative structure and CO2PR catalytic activity of LDHs, and the coordinative effects of the reaction mechanism of CO2PR over LDHs are also needed to reveal. Based on previous research, introducing vacancies into ZnAl-LDH can effectively regulate the catalytic activity of LDHs for CO2PR [21], but the types of vacancies and the influence of vacancy concentration on catalytic activity are still unclear. Therefore, in this work, three types of vacancies in ZnAl-LDH such as (hydrogen vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VH-ZnAl-LDH), hydroxyl vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VOH-ZnAl-LDH) and zinc vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VZn-ZnAl-LDH) are constructed as photocatalysts for CO2PR. The density functional theory (DFT) is used to calculate the structure, charge properties and thermodynamic reaction mechanism. The calculation results show that after introducing vacancies, electrons are concentrated and distributed at the vacancies. In addition, the charge from CO2 flows to catalysts, which is prove the CO2 is activated on the catalyst surfaces. Compared to perfect ZnAl-LDH, VH, and VZn-ZnAl-LDHs, VOH-ZnAl-LDH is screened to be the best CO2PR catalyst since it has the lowest Gibbs free energy barrier for potential-determining step (0.314 eV) and it has good HER inhibition performance (1.11 eV). By reasonably adjusting the concentration of OH vacancies on the surface of LDHs, it is found that vacancy concentration also affects the photocatalytic reduction performance of CO2, and when the OH vacancy concentration is 2/9, it has the lowest potential barrier (0.258 eV) for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4. This work provides a deeper understanding of constructing hydrotalcite photocatalytic materials, and emphasizes that introducing vacancies in LDHs is a potential method for using solar energy to prepare high value-added hydrocarbons and chemicals through photocatalytic CO2 conversion. 2 Computational methods 2.1 Reaction pathways of CO2 reduction reaction The two reaction pathways (HCOO and COOH) for CO2 reduction reaction are calculated in this work are from literature reports [23,24]. As shown in Fig. 1 , the reactant CO2 is adsorbed onto the catalyst surface to form CO2* and then C or O in CO2* combines with hydrogen atom to form COOH* or HCOO* species. For the HCOO pathway, HCOO* intermediate is further hydrogenated to generate HCOOH (Step 3). Subsequently, further hydrogenation is carried out to generate HCHO (Step 11), CH3OH (Step 17) and CH4 (Step 22) species. For the COOH pathway, COOH can generate products through three ways of adding H (Step 4, Step 5, Step 6). In step 4, H is added to C of COOH to generate HCOOH. In step 5, H is added to O of COOH to generate C(OH)2, and in step 6, hydrogenation occurs on OH to dehydrate and generate CO. Finally, after the 8-electron process, the final product CH4 will be generated regardless of which pathway is taken. All the elementary steps of CO2PR (Step 1-Step 22) and Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER, Step 23) are shown in the Table S1 (Supplementary Information). 2.2 Models construction According to report, vacancy-rich in ultrathin ZnAl-LDH nanosheets exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity for CO2 conversion [22]. On this basis, the ZnAl-LDH is selected for the study of photocatalytic reduction of CO2 in this work. The rationality of the pristine ZnAl-LDH structure is crucial, as it serves as the basis for further calculations of modified ZnAl-LDH. Firstly, Zn2Al-NO3-LDH model have been established based on the previously reported crystal data [25]. R = Zn/Al is set to be 2 and NO3 − is chosen as intercalated anion in the model, since NO3-LDHs are commonly found and easily introduced into the interlayer of LDHs to form a stable structure [26,27]. The space group of model is R 3 ¯ m and the cell parameters are α = β = 90°, γ = 120° [28]. The supercell of ZnAl-NO3-LDH is 3 × 3 × 1 in the a-, b-, and c- directions, respectively. The chemical formula of the LDH bulk model is Zn18Al9(OH)54(NO3)9, which contains a total of 171 atoms. (003) surface is selected as reaction surface, since it has been reported to be favorable to expose [29]. The (003) surface structures of hydrogen vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VH-ZnAl-LDH), hydroxyl vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VOH-ZnAl-LDH) and zinc vacancy ZnAl-LDH (VZn-ZnAl-LDH) are further constructed. The initial and optimized (003) surface structures of perfect and vacant ZnAl-LDHs are shown in Fig. 2 a–d. 2.3 Computational details All density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out in CASTEP [30]. The DFT calculations are performed using a plane-wave implementation [31]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof function (PBE) / generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is selected exchange–correlation function [32]. The Tkatchenko Scheffler (TS) method is chosen to correct dispersion interactions, such as hydrogen bonding [33]. The vacuum region between the slabs is set to 15 Å in the z-direction to avoid the interaction between neighboring structures [34]. The cutoff energy is set as 380 eV (For the details of the cutoff energy test, see Figure S1 (Supplementary Information) and the converge tolerances of the force on each relaxed atom below 0.1 eV/Å are used, and the converge criteria of the energy change is 5 × 10−5 eV. The Ab Initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations of VOH-ZnAl-LDH are conducted within the PBE/GGA method. The AIMD simulations are performed in the canonical ensembles (NVT) with the temperature set to 298.0 K. The total simulation time is 4 ps with the time step set to 1.0 fs. Vacancy formation energy (FE) can be used to describe the energy required to create a vacancy in a ZnAl-LDH (003) surface, and its magnitude reflects the difficulty of vacancy formation, which is defined as Eq (1) [35]: (1) F E = E V − slab + E V − gas − E slab where E V-slab, E V-gas and E slab are the total energies for the vacancy slab, the atom in the gas phase and the original surface, respectively. The adsorption energy (E ads) of the adsorbate on the surface is calculated as Eq (2) [36]: (2) E ads = E total − E R − E slab where E total is the is the calculated energy of adsorption configuration containing the adsorbate (R), E R and E slab are the calculated energies of the adsorbate and clean surface in the gas phase, respectively. Gibbs free energy (G) can be used to evaluate whether a reaction is spontaneous, and the Gibbs free energy of each species can be calculated using Eq (3) [37]: (3) G = E + ZPE − T S where E is the total electronic energy of the system based on the DFT calculations, ZPE and S is the zero-point energy and entropy, respectively, T is the system temperature (298.15 K). The Gibbs free energy change for each elementary reaction is based on the calculation of the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), and the calculation expression is shown in Eq (4) [38]: (4) Δ G = G products − G reactants + k T ln 10 · pH − e U where G product and G reactant represents the Gibbs free energy of the reactant and product in 298.15 K, respectively. k B is Boltzmann’s constant, the values of pH and applied bias (U) are set to zero [39]. The Gibbs free energy of (H+ + e −) at standard conditions (101,325 Pa, 298.15 K) is assumed as the Gibbs free energy of 1/2 H2 [40]. The step with the largest Gibbs free energy change among all elementary reactions is the potential-rate determining step (PDS), where ΔG PDS is the free energy barrier for the potential-rate determining step. The Miliken charge and the electronic density difference (Δρ) are calculated in order to investigate the effect of introducing vacancies on (003) crystal planes in LDHs. The charge density difference (Δρ) is calculated by Eq (5) [41]: (5) Δ ρ = Δ ρ tol − Δ ρ sur − Δ ρ A where Δρ tol, Δρ sur, and Δρ A are the electron density of the whole system, of the surface and of the CO2 molecule, respectively. In crystals, the vacancy concentration is usually measured by the number of vacancies, which refers to the ratio of the total number of vacancies to the total number of nodes in the crystal. The concentration of vacancy i on the crystal surface can be defined as Eq 6 [42]: x i = n i / N where ni is the number of vacancies and N is the total number of nodes in the system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The structure and charge properties of the models Due to the frequent presence of vacancies in the preparation of ultra-thin LDHs nanosheets under experimental conditions [43], the difficulty of forming vacancies on the LDHs crystal surface is first considered. The vacancy formation energy (FE, Eq (1)) can be used to analyze the difficulty of vacancy formation on (003) surface of ZnAl-LDH. The results show that FE (VH = 0.31 eV) < FE(VOH = 4.22 eV) < FE (VZn = 4.44 eV) < FE (VAl = 10.94 eV), indicating that the difficulty of forming vacancies on the (003) surface of ZnAl-LDH is VH < VOH < VZn < VAl. From the perspective of chemical bonding, the bond energy of Al-O bond is theoretically greater than that of Zn-O bond, indicating that Al-O bond is more stable and less likely to break than Zn-O bond. Therefore, VH, VOH, and VZn-ZnAl-LDHs are selected as catalysts for photocatalytic reduction of CO2. In order to confirm the stability of introducing vacancies, the VOH-ZnAl-LDH model is selected for Ab Initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation. The AIMD results are plotted in Figure S2 (Supplementary Information), and it can be observed that there are slight fluctuations in energy within 0–4 ps, but the shape of the graph is close to a horizontal line, indicating that its structure has good dynamic stability. The Fig. 2 shows the optimized side view structures of perfect and vacant ZnAl-LDHs, and it can be seen that the laminates of LDHs can be well maintained, indicating the stability of each structure. In order to explore the effect of introducing vacancies, the electronic density difference is further studied. The results are shown in Fig. 3 a–d and Figure S3 (Supplementary Information). It can be clearly seen from Fig. 3 and Figure S3 (Supplementary Information) that regardless of the introduction of VH, VOH, or VZn, compared to perfect LDHs, the red color at the vacancy is darker, indicating that the electron density of LDHs containing vacancies is mainly concentrated at the vacancies. The Millikan charge analysis further applied to analyze the influence of vacancies. From Fig. 3e and Fig. 3f, it can be seen that after introducing VOH, the charges of Zn decreased from 1.42 and 0.79 to 0.85 and 0.74, while the charges of Al decreased from 1.77 to 1.68. Combined with Fig. 3b, it indicates that the charges are mainly concentrated at the VOH region. From Fig. 3e and 3g, it can be seen that after introducing VH, the charge of unsaturated O is −1.03, which is higher than the charge of the corresponding O on the perfect surface (Fig. 3e, −0.97). This indicates that after introducing VH, the charge is mainly concentrated on unsaturated O. Similarly, the introduction of VZn will cause an increase in the charge of O (Fig. 3e and 3h) around the vacancy. Combined with the electronic density difference (Fig. 3d), after introducing VZn in ZnAl-LDH, electrons mainly concentrate at the Zn vacancy. In summary, introducing VOH, VH and VZn into ZnAl-LDH laminates increases the electronic density at the vacancies, indicating that unsaturated coordination atoms can concentrate surface charges around them, which may more effectively absorb and activate reactants. 3.2 The adsorption of CO2 on (003) of perfect and vacant ZnAl-LDHs The adsorption of reactant CO2 by the catalyst is the first and essential step in CO2PR [44]. Therefore, the DFT method is used to simulate the adsorption of CO2 on different types of ZnAl-LDHs catalyst surfaces. As shown in Figure S4 (Supplementary Information), the adsorption energies (Eq (2)) for adsorbed CO2 on VOH, VH and VZn is −0.71, −0.79 and −0.14 eV, respectively. Compared to the perfect ZnAl-LDH, the vacant ZnAl-LDHs have stronger adsorption energy for reactant CO2. In order to explore the electronic behavior of CO2 after adsorption on different ZnAl-LDHs (003) surfaces, the electronic density difference is further studied. It can be seen from Fig. 4 that the colored regions around O and C of CO2 are red and blue, respectively. This suggests that the electronic density of O of CO2 increases apparently. It can also be seen from Fig. 4 that the region of CO2 and region of surface of ZnAl-LDHs overlap partly, indicating that there is a certain interaction between CO2 and surfaces of ZnAl-LDHs. This result is consistent with the result of the adsorption energy. 3.3 Thermodynamical mechanism of CO2PR over ZnAl-LDH From a large number of previous literature and calculations in Section 3.2, it has been shown that vacancies can significantly enhance the activation of reactants by catalysts, which is beneficial for the occurrence of catalytic reactions [17–19,45]. Therefore, the adsorption of intermediates of CO2PR on the (003) surface of vacant-ZnAl-LDHs are calculated (Figure S5-S7, Supplementary Information). Because in most published literatures on photocatalytic reactions, thermodynamic mechanism based on Gibbs free energy changes is widely accepted [24,34,39], and the definition of transition states becomes ambiguous due to changes in the number of charge carriers involved in the photocatalytic process [46]. Therefore, the transition state and the activation energies of the potential-determining steps are not considered, the DFT method to calculate Gibbs free energy changes is chosen in our work to calculate the thermodynamic mechanism of CO2PR. The Gibbs free energy changes of each elementary step (Table S1, Supplementary Information) of ZnAl-LDHs are calculated by Eq (3) and Eq (4) and the HCOO and COOH pathway with the minimum Gibbs free energy (optimal path) of photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CH4 on VOH, VH, VZn-ZnAl-LDHs are displayed in Fig. 5 a–c and the numbers represent the Gibbs free energy barriers of the PDS for the formation of CH4 product generated by the HCOO and COOH pathways, respectively. The thermodynamic Gibbs free energy and the band gap energy (3.059 eV) of perfect-ZnAl-LDH photocatalytic reduction of CO2 are based on the data from literature [23]. From Figure S9 (Supplementary Information) and Table S2 (Supplementary Information), it can be seen that introducing vacancies will reduce the band gap energy of perfect-ZnAl-LDH, while the effect on the position of the conduction band is not significant. Further investigation revealed that for all the calculated ZnAl-LDHs, the driving force can overcome the Gibbs free energy barrier of PDS to form CH4. As shown in Fig. 5a, for VOH-ZnAl-LDH, the potential-determining step of the COOH pathway is the first protonation process (Step 1: CO2* + H+ + e − → COOH*) with a potential barrier of 0.314 eV, while the potential-determining step of the HCOO pathway is the second hydrogenation process (Step 4) with the Gibbs free energy barrier 0.456 eV, i.e. COOH* + H+ + e − → HCOOH*. It can be seen from Fig. 5b and 5c, the PDS of the HCOO pathway for CO2PR by VH and VZn-ZnAl-LDHs are the same, which is the first protonation process of CO2* to HCOO* (Step 1), with the Gibbs free energy barriers of 0.512 eV and 0.960 eV, respectively. For VH-ZnAl-LDH, the PDS of the COOH pathway is the hydrogenation of COOH from CO2 (Step 2), while the PDS of the COOH pathway is the dehydration of CH3OH combined with H proton to generate CH3 (Step 20) for VZn-ZnAl-LDH. Unlike catalysts VH- and VZn-ZnAl-LDH, the optimal pathway for VOH-ZnAl-LDH to catalyze CO2 reduction to CH4 is: CO2* → COOH*→ HCOOH* → CHO* → HCHO* → CH2OH* → CH2* → CH3* → CH4* (Step 2 → Step 4 → Step 7 → Step 11 → Step 14 → Step 18 → Step 21 → Step 22), while the optimal pathways for VH-, VZn-ZnAl-LDH two catalysts to catalyze CO2 reduction to CH4 are: CO2* → COOH* → HCOOH* → CHO* → HCHO* → CH2OH* → CH3OH* → CH3* → CH4* (Step 2 → Step 4 → Step 7 → Step 11 → Step 14 → Step 17 → Step 20 → Step 22), which is the same as catalyst perfect-ZnAl-LDH [23]. The minimum free energy value for CO2 reduction on perfect and vacant ZnAl-LDHs through HCOO and COOH pathways are showed in Fig. 5d and the value of perfect ZnAl-LDH comes from the reference literature [23]. It can be seen from Fig. 5d that the introduction of vacancies reduces the Gibbs free energy barrier of the minimum free energy pathway for COOH and HCOO pathways compared to the perfect-ZnAl-LDH. In addition, regardless of the catalyst, the COOH pathway is the minimum free energy pathway for CO2 to generate CH4 compared to the HCOO pathway. Among them, VOH-ZnAl-LDH has the lowest Gibbs free energy barrier for photocatalytic reduction of CO2. This indicates that VOH-ZnAl-LDH has good catalytic activity for CO2PR, and the reaction preferentially undergoes the COOH pathway on the VOH-ZnAl-LDH catalyst. In addition, the conversion of CO2PR to CO has been widely used because CO is an important chemical raw material, such as the Fischer-Tropsch process, the Monsanto process, and so on [47–50]. Therefore, the mechanism of introducing VH, VOH, VZn vacancies in ZnAl-LDH for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO is further discussed. The CO2PR to produce CO mainly goes through the COOH pathway [51,52], which is completed in two steps (Step 2 → Step 5, Fig. 1). One step is the protonation of CO2 to produce COOH intermediate (Step 2), and the other step is the protonation and dehydration of COOH to produce CO (Step 5). The Gibbs free energy barrier diagram of ZnAl-LDH containing vacancies photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO are shown in Figure S10 (Supplementary Information). As shown in Figure S10 (Supplementary Information), the Gibbs free energy barriers for the CO2PR to CO by ZnAl-LDH containing vacancies are lower than those of perfect-ZnAl-LDH (ΔG PDS = 0.842 eV), indicating that introducing vacancies can reduce the Gibbs free energy barrier of the reaction and promote the conversion of CO2 to CO. 3.4 Competition of HER Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a common side reaction in photocatalytic reduction of CO2, which can affect the efficiency of the CO2PR [53]. HER is often evaluated through a three state diagram, which consists of an initial H + state, an intermediate H* state, and H2 as the final product [54]. The adsorption of H on the catalyst surface is the potential-determining step of the HER [55]. Therefore, the HER performance of VOH-ZnAl-LDH catalyst is further studied. As shown in Fig. 5e, the Gibbs free energy barrier for the HER process in VOH-ZnAl-LDH catalyst is 1.11 eV, while the Gibbs free energy barrier for VOH-ZnAl-LDH photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4 is 0.314 eV. This result is consistent with the result in the literature that the monolayer LDHs containing vacancies can effectively suppress H2 evolution and achieve highly selective reduction of CO2 under irradiation above 600 nm [56]. 3.5 The influence of adsorption sites on CO2PR As can be seen from Sections 3.1 and 3.2, vacancies can effectively activate the reactant CO2, thereby facilitating the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 reaction. In order to compare the effects of reactants and intermediate species on the reaction at vacancies and not at vacancies, further investigation is conducted on the influence of the adsorption of reactants and intermediates at VOH-ZnAl-LDH sites away from vacancies (VOH-far-ZnAl-LDH) on the reaction. Firstly, the adsorption energy (Eq (2)) of CO2 far from the OH vacancy (VOH-far-ZnAl-LDH) is calculated, and it is found that the adsorption energy is almost the same as that of CO2 on the perfect-ZnAl-LDH surface, much lower than that on VOH-ZnAl-LDH (Figure S4, Supplementary Information). Further exploration is conducted on the mechanism of VOH-far-ZnAl-LDH as a catalyst for CO2PR. The adsorption sites of the intermediates of CO2 reduction on the surface of VOH-far-ZnAl-LDH (003) are calculated (Figure S8, Supplementary Information) and the minimum free energy diagram for CO2 reduction on VOH-far-ZnAl-LDH (003) surface through HCOO and COOH pathways is showed in Fig. 5f. As shown in Fig. 5f, the Gibbs free energy barrier for CO2 to generate CH4 through the COOH pathway is 0.586 eV, and the potential-determining step is the Step 2, i.e. CO2* + H+ + e − → COOH*. While the potential-determining step in HCOO pathway is HCOO* → HCOOH* (Step 3) with a Gibbs free energy barrier of 1.646 eV. From above, it can be concluded that the ΔG PDS of these two pathways and the ΔG PDS of perfect-ZnAl-LDH (HCOO pathway: 1.885 eV, COOH pathway: 0.381 eV) are almost the same [23], much lower than the ΔG PDS of the two pathways at the vacancy (Fig. 5a), indicating that the reactants and intermediate species are located far away from the vacancy or at the perfect structural position, which has almost the same effect on the photocatalytic reduction of CO2, and has little impact on the mechanism of CO2PR. Therefore, the adsorption of reactants and intermediate species at vacancies is more conducive to the occurrence of CO2PR. 3.5 The influence of vacancy concentration on CO2PR The concentration and distribution of vacancies have an extremely important impact on the electron transport process on the catalyst surface, which in turn affects the efficiency of the reduction reaction [57]. Therefore, the effect of OH vacancy concentration on the CO2PR on the ZnAl-LDH (003) surface is further consideration. As Figure S5, S11-S12 (Supplementary Information), 1/9, 2/9 and 1/3 concentrations of OH vacancies are regulated on the first layer of ZnAl-LDH (003) surface. The mechanism of photocatalytic reduction of CO2 with 1/9 OH vacancy concentration is shown in Fig. 5a. The adsorption of intermediates of CO2PR on the ZnAl-LDHs (003) surface with different OH vacancy concentrations are showed in Figure S11-S12 (Supplementary Information), and the minimum free energy diagrams for CO2 reduction on ZnAl-LDHs surfaces with 2/9 and 1/3 OH vacancies through HCOO and COOH pathways are shown in Fig. 6 a–b. As shown in Fig. 6a, the COOH pathway (ΔG PDS = 0.258 eV) of LDHs with 2/9 OH vacancy concentration has a lower Gibbs free energy barrier for reducing CO2 to CH4 compared to the HCOO pathway (ΔG PDS = 0.416 eV), and the potential-determining step is the Step 22 (CH3* + H+ + e − → CH4*). From Fig. 6b, it can be seen that when the OH vacancy concentration is 1/3, the COOH pathway is the optimal pathway for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4, and the potential energy barrier of PDS is 0.693 eV. Comparing the mechanism of introducing different OH vacancy on the ZnAl-LDHs surface for catalytic reduction of CO2, it is found that the COOH pathway is the optimal pathway, and the optimal pathway is: CO2* → COOH*→ HCOOH* → CHO* → HCHO* → CH2OH* → CH2* → CH3*→ CH4*, and when the OH vacancy concentration is 2/9, it has the best photocatalytic reduction performance for CO2 to CH4 (Fig. 6c). Therefore, the concentration of OH vacancies have a significant impact on this reduction reaction. By adjusting the vacancy concentration reasonably, the performance of the catalyst can be optimized, and the activity and stability of the reduction reaction can be improved. 4 Conclusion In this work, the density functional theory (DFT) is performed to calculate the structure, charge properties such as Miliken charge and the electronic density difference of hydrogen vacancy (VH), hydroxyl vacancy (VOH) and zinc vacancy (VZn) ZnAl-LDHs, and the thermodynamic mechanism of CO2PR over these LDHs. Electronic properties (Miliken charge and the electronic density difference) analysis shows that compared with the perfect ZnAl-LDH (003), the electron density of LDHs containing vacancies is mainly concentrated at the vacancies. The introduction of vacancies enhances the adsorption and activation of reactant CO2, which is beneficial for subsequent hydrogenation processes. The calculation of the HCOO pathway and COOH pathway mechanisms for CO2PR using three different catalysts shows that compared to perfect ZnAl-LDH, introducing vacancies can reduce the Gibbs free energy barriers for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO and CH4, and the COOH pathway is the optimal reaction pathway. The CO2PR has the lowest energy barrier for the PDS along the COOH pathway on the VOH-ZnAl-LDH (0.314 eV) and it has good HER inhibition performance (1.11 eV), which indicates that VOH-ZnAl-LDH is a very promising catalyst for CO2PR among the calculated ones. Further comparison of the reaction mechanisms between reactant CO2 and intermediate species at and away from OH vacancy indicates that vacancy is more conducive to catalytic reactions. By adjusting the OH vacancy concentrations reasonably, the performance of the catalyst can be optimized and when the vacancy concentration is 2/9, there is good photocatalytic reduction performance to CO2. This work lays a useful foundation for the rational design and practical application of two-dimensional LDHs materials based on vacancy regulation, and provides theoretical information and guidance for the design of efficient photocatalytic materials for CO2PR. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2PR) into hydrocarbons is one of the most promising technologies to address global energy demand and environmental issues, and vacancy engineering can significantly enhance the activity of photocatalysts in CO2PR. Herein, the structure, charge properties of vacant ZnAl-LDHs (hydrogen vacancy: VH, hydroxyl vacancy: VOH, zinc vacancy: VZn) and the thermodynamic mechanism of CO2PR over these LDHs are investigated by using density functional theory. The calculation results indicate that the introduction of vacancies can promote the adsorption and activation of reactant CO2. Compared to perfect ZnAl-LDH, introducing vacancies can reduce the Gibbs free energy barriers for CO2PR to CO and CH4. The analysis of the Gibbs free energy barriers of potential-determining step (ΔG PDS) and HER suggests that VOH-ZnAl-LDH is the best CO2PR catalyst. By comparing the adsorption of reactants and intermediate species at different positions on the catalyst, it is found that species adsorption at vacancies is more conducive to the occurrence of catalytic reactions. Regulating the OH concentrations on the surface of LDHs also affects the catalytic activity of the catalyst, and when the concentration is 2/9, it has the lowest Gibbs free energy (0.258 eV) barrier for CO2PR to CH4. This work provides theoretical guidance for understanding the photocatalytic performance of LDHs materials containing vacancies for CO2PR, and provides useful directions for designing and preparing efficient CO2PR catalysts.
